description: Maj. Gen. John J. Pershing, commander of the American Expeditionary Force in Europe, was not too busy to request a dozen copies of his cover photo.
title: ‘Black Jack’ Pershing, Commander and Fanboy
title_page: ‘Black Jack’ Pershing, Commander and Fanboy - The New York Times
maintext:
We get letters.
But not many like the one that arrived on Aug. 23, 1917, from France.
“My dear Sir,” wrote Maj. Gen. John J. Pershing, commander of the American Expeditionary Force in Europe. “I am just in receipt of your issue of May thirty-first, which contains my portrait, and am writing to say that this the best portrait I have ever seen of myself.
“Would it be possible to get a few prints of it — say about a dozen? If so please send them to me at my headquarters here in France.
“Truly and sincerely yours.”
Image Maj. Gen. John J. Pershing. Credit... Central News Service/The New York Times Mid-Week Pictorial, May 31, 1917
The file folder from which this remarkable letter emerged contained no indication of whether we fulfilled the request, though it’s hard to imagine saying no to a general whose nickname was “Black Jack.”
